title: Buy United Technologies Stock Now, Not After Its Split and Merger, Analyst Says
text:
Text size

Since United Technologies announced plans for a $50 billion blockbuster deal to merge with defense contractor Raytheon the combined value of both entities has dropped by about 1%, or $2 billion. The S&P 500, by comparison, has gained 2% since the June 9 announcement.

Investors, it seems, aren’t too enthused about the combination, which will create an aerospace and defense giant. Still, Cowen analyst Cai von Rumohr is bullish on United Tech’s aerospace division and recommends buying stock in the company today.

Of course, it could be that investors don’t mind the merger, they are just tired of waiting.

United Technologies (ticker: UTX) announced in late 2018 that it is breaking into three companies: one dedicated to aerospace, one to air-conditioning and another dedicated to elevators. Only after the three-way split wraps up in the first part of 2020 will the aerospace division merge with Raytheon (RTN). So it could be eight or nine more months before the stand-alone defense and aerospace giant trades publicly. Investors’ patience is being tested.

“Investors seem fixated on the [Raytheon] merger but under-appreciate major cyclical turns at Otis [and] Pratt, [United Tech’s] recession resistance, and likely [second-half earnings] beats,” von Rumohr said in a Wednesday research report. “With [the] separation [and] merger on track, transactional overhang should abate, offering upside to our $150 [price target].”

Otis is United Technologies’ elevator division and Pratt is short for Pratt & Whitney, part of United Technologies aerospace division that makes jet engines.

Von Rumohr thinks Pratt’s engine profit margins are going higher because of the company’s product cycle. New engines are sold at low, or no, profit margin because jet-engine makers make money servicing assets over their operating lives. What’s more, early in a product’s life cycle, volumes are often low, leading to poor fixed-cost absorption. It is always better for profitability to sell more volume out of the same facility.

“Pratt’s total margin looks set for gradual up trend through 2023,” he wrote. As important, margin improvement, according to the analyst, isn’t dependent on the economy making United Technologies aerospace margins recession resistant.

He likes the defense deal, too. “We like the proposed [Raytheon] merger for technology synergies and enhanced financial flexibility to bolster [cash flow] by 2021,” von Rumohr said. He thinks the merger makes strategic sense and upgraded United Tech stock on June 24, a few weeks after the Raytheon merger was announced.

Von Rumohr rates United Tech stock Outperform, the Cowen equivalent of Buy, with a $150 price target, 14% higher than recent levels.

As the United Tech spinoffs and the Raytheon merger approach, Wall Street will start commenting on the valuation of the individual United Tech pieces. For now, it is hard to say what anything is worth—debt allocations, for instance, between divisions aren’t decided and, of course, there are no share counts for the new entities. William Blair wrote a bullish report on Otis on Tuesday, saying the elevator unit could trade at a better valuation multiple than United Tech does today. Now Cowen is positive on United Tech aerospace.

Looking ahead, investors may be interested in individual units, but they will have to be content with owning the entire company for now because that’s the only thing for sale.

United Technologies stock rose 1.6% to $131.05 on Wednesday, better than the 0.9% gain of the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Cowen analyst Cai von Rumohr is bullish on United Technologies’ aerospace division and recommends buying stock in the company today, not waiting until after its split and subsequent merger with Raytheon.
